citation.article-title: Five new species of the genus Catenuloplanes: Catenuloplanes niger sp. nov., Catenuloplanes indicus sp. nov., Catenuloplanes atrovinosus sp. nov., Catenuloplanes castaneus sp. nov., and Catenuloplanes nepalensis sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Catenuloplanes indicus sp. nov.
Catenuloplanes indicus (in'di.cus. L. masc. adj. indicus, pertaining to India, where the organism was isolated)
The morphological, physiological, and chemotaxonomic characteristics are the same as those given previously for C. japonicus (10).

In addition, C. indicus grows at 37Â°C and does not produce any soluble pigment in inorganic salts-starch agar (ISP medium 4), tyrosine agar (ISP medium 7), Bennett agar, and Bennett agar containing maltose.
Susceptible to penicillin, cephaloridine, cephalexin, and benzylpenicillin.
The G+C content of the DNA is 71.3 to 71.9 mol%; the G+C content of the DNA of the type strain is 71.3 mol%.
The type strain is strain IFO 15575 (= RA328).
